title: Question 20

children: This question has been updated as a result of postpublication analysis and/or new data that are relevant to the question.

A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for intermittent double vision that occurs when she looks from the corner of her eyes and disappears when she covers one eye. She also reports fluctuating weakness and frequent nausea and diarrhea. She has had a history of exercise intolerance and intermittent muscle cramps since middle school. She also has postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, and fibromyalgia. Her sister, brother, mother, and maternal aunt have similar muscle, neurologic, and multiorgan symptoms, but her father and a second brother do not. Current medications are propranolol and duloxetine.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. BMI is 20. There is bilateral impairment of ocular adduction along with bilateral ptosis. Lower facial muscles show weakness. Muscle tone is reduced, but deep tendon reflexes are preserved. Proximal weakness is noted in all extremities. There is no delayed relaxation with grip or percussion. Mental status, sensory examination, and coordination are intact.
Electromyogram shows myopathic changes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Mitochondrial myopathy is associated with fluctuating weakness, ophthalmoplegia, multiorgan symptoms, and maternal inheritance.
The most likely diagnosis is mitochondrial myopathy (
Option E

). Mitochondrial diseases are a group of genetic disorders caused by dysfunction of the mitochondria and may present as myopathies, neuropathies, and multisystemic diseases with maternal inheritance. Maternal inheritance is a unique and distinctive feature of mitochondrial DNA. Offspring of affected fathers do not inherit these diseases, but all offspring regardless of sex are at equal risk for inheriting the disease when a mother possesses the mutation. Each cell carries multiple copies of the mitochondrial genome and deleterious mutations usually affect some but not all copies of the mitochondrial genome. The expression of disease due to mitochondrial DNA depends on the relative proportions of normal and abnormal mitochondrial DNA. This means that there can be substantial variation in the likelihood of developing the disease and the disease severity. In this case, three of the offspring are affected because of this variable expression of disease. Mitochondrial disorders can present with a wide range of fluctuating symptoms, including weakness, autonomic dysfunction, gastrointestinal motility disorders, chronic pain, vision and hearing disorders, and cardiovascular disease. In this patient, fluctuating weakness, ophthalmoplegia, multiorgan symptoms, and family history should prompt consideration of mitochondrial myopathy.
Acid maltase deficiency (Pompe disease) (
Option A

), an autosomal recessive disorder, can present in adulthood. This condition may be associated with progressive rather than fluctuating weakness in proximal and respiratory muscles. It is diagnosed by assessing acid maltase activity in leukocytes and genetic testing for the acid Î±-glucosidase gene.
Becker muscular dystrophy (
Option B

) is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by dystrophinopathy associated with progressive weakness and cardiomyopathy. The clinical course is milder than that of related Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and these patients are sometimes seen in an adult clinic. Because of X-linked transmission, this condition is not expected in a female patient even though female carriers of dystrophin gene may develop hyperCKemia or nocturnal cramps. In addition, a fluctuating course, ophthalmoplegia, and multiorgan involvement (except for the heart) are not expected in this disorder.
Inclusion body myositis (
Option C

) is a late-onset (after age 50 years) sporadic inflammatory myopathy diagnosed more often in men than in women. Symptoms involve asymmetric weakness predominantly in quadriceps and bulbar muscles and distal upper extremities. Involvement of extraocular muscles and multiorgan involvement is not expected.
McArdle disease (
Option D

), an autosomal recessive disorder causing myophosphorylase deficiency, is a metabolic myopathy associated with isolated exercise-induced weakness, cramps, and myoglobinuria. Ophthalmoplegia and multiorgan involvement are not expected in this condition.

references: Gorman GS, Chinnery PF, DiMauro S, et al. Mitochondrial diseases. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2016;2:16080.
